item.title: In Front-Line Ukrainian Towns, Those Who Stayed Become Moving Targets
item.description: Three-and-a-half years into the war, the conflict is growing deadlier for civilians, with explosive drones reshaping life in front-line towns and villages.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Nikolaienko

item.title: He Jokes About Trump and Invading Kenya—and May Be Uganda’s Next President
item.description: Muhoozi Kainerugaba, son of the longtime ruler, oversees a key U.S. military partner while boasting about torture and threatening to arrest members of parliament.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Opinion | Trump’s Gunboat War on Drugs
item.description: Venezuelan capos get a kinetic message, and so does kingpin Maduro.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | China’s Military Parade Was a Message
item.description: Trump saw Xi warmly welcome Putin and Kim. What’s his response?
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Three Big Lies About the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Even people I respect are repeating these foolish notions.
item.dc:creator: Bernard-Henri Lévy

item.title: Rubio Reassures Mexico After U.S. Military Strike Jolts Region
item.description: The secretary of state agreed to strengthen security cooperation with Mexico a day after a strike against a drug-carrying boat in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Kejal Vyas

item.title: ‘Operation Wrath of God’ Review: A Campaign of Vengeance
item.description: Israel’s European partners, despite misgivings about assassinations, helped Mossad develop its “kill list” after the Munich massacre.

item.title: Bank of England’s Bailey Sees More Doubt About Timing of Next Rate Cut
item.description: The Bank of England is likely to continue to lower its key interest rate, but the timing of future moves is now more uncertain, Gov. Andrew Bailey said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: China Flaunts Military Might With Lavish Parade—and Sends Warning to Washington
item.description: Xi Jinping rolls out his latest weapons and a red carpet for Russia’s Vladimir Putin and North Korea’s Kim Jong Un.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: How Jet Lag Cost the Global Face of Japan Inc. His Job
item.description: A scandal surrounding the chief of Jim Beam owner Suntory Holdings has deprived corporate Japan of a rare asset.
item.dc:creator: Junko Fukutome

item.title: EU Closes in on Trade Deal with South American Bloc
item.description: The agreement would create the EU’s biggest free-trade zone of more than 700 million consumers.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: A Guide to China’s New Weapons on Parade in Beijing
item.description: China used a military parade to showcase a sophisticated new arsenal that it can use to challenge U.S. power in the Asia-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: China Is Using the Private Sector to Advance Military AI
item.description: A variety of companies and universities is helping the country’s forces to modernize with cutting-edge technology, data shows.
item.dc:creator: Josh Chin

item.title: The Woman Trump Calls Europe’s Most Powerful Leader
item.description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has become a go-to contact for the White House over trade and Ukraine, but she faces fresh tests from both sides of the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Opinion | Bond Traders Sing the Blues
item.description: Heavily indebted governments are increasingly vulnerable to bond vigilantes.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | How Tariffs Hurt My American Factory
item.description: Some of my rivals that produce overseas will be less hard-hit.
item.dc:creator: George Matouk Jr.

item.title: Opinion | Trump’s Disoriented Democrats
item.description: The Steele dossier party is a demoralized mess instead of a functional check.
item.dc:creator: Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

item.title: Israel Hit Yemen Target Just Hours After Discovering an Imminent Houthi Meeting
item.description: An attack that killed Houthi government officials shows how Israel has ramped up its intelligence on the rebel group—and its readiness to strike early and hard.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: Afghan Quake Death Toll Rises to 1,400 Amid Aftershocks
item.description: Rescuers struggled to reach survivors in the remote mountainous region where secondary tremors struck following the magnitude-6.0 quake on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: Russia, China Close In on Pipeline Deal, Leaving Beijing With the Upper Hand
item.description: The two countries advanced plans for the long-delayed pipeline to funnel Russian fuel to China but left core terms unresolved, a sign of Beijing’s growing leverage.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: EU to Move Forward With South American Trade Agreement
item.description: A long-awaited trade agreement will be presented on Wednesday as Brussels races to secure trade deals while tensions with the U.S. mount.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: AI-Powered Drone Swarms Have Now Entered the Battlefield
item.description: In a new frontier for warfare, Ukraine is using technology to allow groups of drones to communicate and make decisions independent of their operator.
item.dc:creator: Alistair MacDonald

item.title: The Black Market for Oil Blunts Trump’s India Tariffs
item.description: The extra levy meant to punish New Delhi for buying cheap Russian crude isn’t going as expected.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Kim Jong Un’s Missiles Fly. He Doesn’t.
item.description: Lacking a reliable aircraft, the North Korean leader took the slow train to Beijing for a gathering of global leaders—right after touring a missile facility.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: The Israeli Army Is Struggling to Get Reservists to Show Up
item.description: As a Gaza City offensive looms and tens of thousands of troops are called up, commanders are finding it harder to get people to report for duty.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: Xi Revisits WWII to Boost China in Great-Power Rivalry With U.S.
item.description: Eight decades after the end of World War II, China’s Communist Party is still battling for recognition of its role in securing victory and its claims to the territorial spoils.
item.dc:creator: Chun Han Wong

item.title: Russia Intensifies Strikes in Ukraine, Defying Trump’s Shifting Deadlines for Peace
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin is expanding his strikes on Ukrainian cities and pressing for further military gains in defiance of President Trump’s deadlines to enter serious peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Hundreds Killed in 6.0-Magnitude Earthquake in Afghanistan
item.description: Authorities said more than 800 people have died, and thousands more are injured. Mountainous terrain and landslides are complicating rescue efforts.
item.dc:creator: Margherita Stancati

item.title: Behind Indonesia Protests, a Growing Economy That Doesn’t Deliver
item.description: Economists have questioned the country’s rosy GDP data and other statistics, as protesters demand action against economic hardships.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: Chinese, Russian, Indian Leaders Pledge Cooperation, in a Message to Trump
item.description: The leaders met at a regional summit in a display of unity that underscored the challenges faced by President Trump’s unorthodox approach to world affairs.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: U.K. Secures $13.5 Billion Deal to Supply Warships to Norway
item.description: The deal would strengthen both Norway’s and NATO’s ability to patrol and protect the maritime areas in the region, Norway’s PM Jonas Gahr Store said.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: USA250 | A Letter From The Wall Street Journal’s Editor in Chief
item.description: Over the next year, we are celebrating America’s 250 years of economic dynamism with special coverage.

item.title: With Another Government on the Brink of Collapse, Is France the New Italy?
item.description: France is reaching a level of fiscal and political dysfunction reminiscent of its Southern European neighbor a decade ago.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: China Ups Surveillance of Troubled People to Quell Rising Unrest
item.description: The Communist Party’s new ‘society work’ agency helps with emotional and economic setbacks while monitoring dissatisfied people.
item.dc:creator: Shen Lu

item.title: Israel Says It Has Killed Hamas Spokesman in Gaza City Strike Ahead of Planned Invasion
item.description: Abu Obeida was one of the few surviving senior Hamas leaders in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Suha Ma’ayeh

item.title: Warren Buffett’s Son Battles Colombia’s Booming Cocaine Trade
item.description: “We’re trying to chip away at it,” Howard Buffett says, describing the programs he is funding to coax drug farmers to switch to legal crops.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Populist Right-Wing Parties Lead Polls in Europe’s Biggest Economies
item.description: For the first time, far-right parties are leading in the U.K., France, and Germany—the latest sign of growing voter discontent across the continent.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: U.S. Tariffs on India Skirt Its Biggest Buyer of Russian Oil
item.description: Reliance Industries accounts for about a third of the Russian oil India imports.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Key Houthi Leader Killed in Israeli Airstrike
item.description: Days of confusion over the fate of one of the leaders of the Houthi rebel movement in Yemen ended when the militia said its prime minister had been killed in an Israeli airstrike.
item.dc:creator: Sudarsan Raghavan

item.title: While Trump Rattles the World, China Basks in the Limelight
item.description: The leaders of three of the world’s four most powerful nations will meet in China this weekend to discuss how to react to the upending of the international order by the U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Even the Injured Are Struggling to Get Out of Gaza
item.description: Despite the Israeli government’s quiet planning to relocate Palestinians from Gaza, it remains difficult for most Gazans to leave the enclave, even if they need urgent medical care.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Habjouqa

item.title: The U.K. Tried to Clamp Down on Migration—and Wound Up With an Unprecedented Wave
item.description: Britain’s post-Brexit visa program, meant to attract lower numbers of skilled workers, soon backfired. The debacle drew populist Nigel Farage back into politics.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: India Braces for the Pain of Trump’s Stiff Tariffs
item.description: Duties that just took effect will hit billions of dollars of trade and hurt Indian sectors ranging from textiles to farming.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Mexico’s Cartels Are Exporting Their Bloody Rivalry to Ecuador and Beyond
item.description: The two most powerful drug rings are locked in a turf war over control of a key South American smuggling route. The bodies are piling up.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: The Ukrainian Attacks That Are Forcing Russia to Ration Its Fuel
item.description: The late Sen. John McCain once called Russia “a gas station with nukes.” Now, because of Ukrainian attacks, it must ration fuel.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: Top Chinese Trade Negotiator Set to Head to U.S. as Talks Resume
item.description: Li Chenggang is expected to travel to Washington this week in a sign that the U.S. and China seek to establish regular dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Mexican Cartel Patriarch Pleads Guilty to U.S. Drug Charges
item.description: Ismael “El Mayo” Zambada, the Sinaloa cartel’s leader for 40 years, was charged with smuggling tons of drugs into the U.S.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Russia Covets This Ukraine Province Above All. These Maps and Charts Show Why.
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin thinks he can make a hugely significant strategic gain at the negotiating table rather than on the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Barnett

item.title: Decades After Genocide, Rwanda Emerges as Aggressive Regional Power
item.description: The tiny country has evolved from an object of sympathy into a controversial and feared powerhouse.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Trump Gives Familiar Two-Week Deadline for Next Steps to End War in Ukraine
item.description: President Trump offered a new—and familiar—deadline for the leaders of Russia and Ukraine to move forward with a peace process or else face possible U.S. retaliation, saying he’d make a determination within “two weeks.”
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: Canada to Remove 25% Tariff on Some U.S. Goods
item.description: The move is seen as a sign of goodwill from Ottawa as it tries to reset its trading relationship with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Police Helicopter Downed by Drone in Colombia, Killing 12
item.description: A Black Hawk was attacked by cocaine-trafficking group, officials said, the latest in an escalating series of drone attacks against security forces.
item.dc:creator: Juan Forero

item.title: Trump Rolled Out the Red Carpet for Putin. He Got Little in Return.
item.description: The meeting between the U.S. president and the Russian leader didn’t appear to yield any breakthroughs.
item.dc:creator: Meridith McGraw

item.title: Sudan’s Famine Enters Dangerous New Phase
item.description: Here’s what to know as critical farmlands get dragged into the country’s devastating civil war.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Refugees in Africa Fight Over Food as U.S. Aid Cuts Take Hold
item.description: The impact of America’s cuts is rippling across the continent.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Why India Can’t Afford to Jettison Its Relationship With Russia
item.description: Despite the threat of U.S. tariffs, New Delhi is resisting pressure to cut longtime ties with Moscow that have brought economic and geopolitical benefits.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Vance’s British Vacation Is Latest Sign of White House’s Soft Spot for U.K.
item.description: Vice President JD Vance arrived in Britain to kick off a 10-day visit that includes a weekend stay with U.K. Foreign Secretary David Lammy, followed by a family holiday.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Andrews

item.title: Bank of England Cuts Rates After Tight Vote
item.description: The U.K. central bank lowered its key rate for the fifth time in a year as it seeks to balance a pickup in inflation against a cooling jobs market.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: India Defies Trump on Russian Oil Despite Tariff Threats
item.description: Indian experts believe the U.S. president is trying to gain short-term leverage in trade negotiations with New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: In a Country Trump Says Nobody’s Heard Of, Tariffs Bring Chaos
item.description: President Trump promised Africa that trade would replace aid, but in one of the world’s poorest countries his administration is slashing both.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Trump Sought Escape on His Summer Golf Vacation. Some Scots Thought Otherwise.
item.description: A small group of protesters greeted the president at his golf course on Scotland’s west coast.

item.title: Hopes Rise for U.S.-Europe Trade Deal as Trump Visits Scotland
item.description: Trump and Ursula von der Leyen, a top EU top official, are set to meet Sunday during president’s golf trip.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Africa Wants Its Critical Minerals to Yield Jobs, Not Just Dollars
item.description: The Trump administration wants to cut deals to secure more of the key materials, but African countries are imposing export restrictions to help develop their own industries.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.

item.title: France’s Macron Tries to Quell New Caledonia Riots With Globe-Crossing Trip
item.description: The French leader said he is open to suspending a voting-rights bill that sparked the riots once order is restored on the archipelago and talks resume between rival factions.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: France Rushes Reinforcements to Riot-Stricken New Caledonia
item.description: Unrest in the overseas territory could derail President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to restore French influence in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: Australia to Boost Defense Spending Amid U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Australia is boosting its defense budget and rethinking its defense plans as strategic competition between the U.S. and China heats up in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
